awd_titl_txt: Phase II IUCRC at Colorado School of Mines:  Center for Manufacturing & Materials Joining Innovation Center (Ma2JIC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Manufacturing and Materials Joining Innovation Center (Ma2JIC) addresses the question of infrastructure rebuilding and innovative materials application in modern manufacturing which are of national interest. The Ma2JIC Center establishes an environment between universities and industrial partners that promotes the development and application of fundamental knowledge in the areas of materials joining and additive manufacturing and provides a platform for the education of the next generation of scientists and engineers. As one of the sites since its inception, the Colorado School of Mines (CSM) Site has complemented the Center with its unique expertise and laboratory facilities in the design and manufacturing of innovative welding materials, welding and joining process innovation, welding materials characterization, and additive manufacturing for the energy, aerospace, oil and gas, and manufacturing industries. The CSM Site will seek to intensify its collaborations with the other Center Sites to jointly develop collaborations with the welding, joining and manufacturing industries, large and small, national laboratories and government agencies. The strength of the Center is the ability of the group to close the gap between materials development and weldability for materials used in the manufacturing industry, with ultimate societal gain from all these amazing synergies.

The Ma2JIC Center research thrusts of Process Innovation, Materials Performance, Additive Manufacturing, Weldability Testing and Evaluation will develop fundamental understanding as described by the materials tetrahedron - "Processing-Microstructure-Properties-Performance".  CSM Site researchers are examining the fundamental aspects of GTA and Laser weldability of Laser-Powder bed fusion AM built products, solidification behavior of Laser-Powder bed fusion and Directed Energy Deposition AM products, and filler metal development for microstructural optimization in Electron Beam Freeform Fabrication products, including metal matrix composites. The incorporation of Reaction Synthesis powder into tubular wires for both laser-based and electron beam-based additive manufacturing is being attempted. The effect of surface tension on AM deposits will be fully characterized and understood for process control.  Another research focus addresses the design and manufacture of thermal spray coatings with enhanced wear and fracture resistance for oil and gas drilling operations. The CSM Site will continue to study and design low transformation temperature welding (LTTW) consumables for distortion control and residual stress mitigation control. These programs are expected to lead to the development of fundamental knowledge as well as practical technology. The CSM Site is also pursuing cross university and multi-industry collaboration on intelligent welding, friction stir processing, robotics, advanced neutron and X-rays characterization, and data-driven modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

por.por_cntn:
Manufacturing and Materials Joining Research Center (Ma2JIC) was originally founded in 2010 as CIMJSEA in Phase I, which focused primarily on energy sector materials joining applications. As the Center membership and market evolved, our Phase II center reflected those changes and our widened focus on manufacturing and materials joining. 

During the entire life of this award, Ma2JIC has established a collaborative research environment between universities and industrial partners that promotes the development and application of fundamental knowledge in materials joining and metal additive manufacturing and provides a platform for the education of the next generation of scientists and engineers. Overall outcomes at the Colorado School of Mines (CSM) site include:

(1) Active outreach efforts were made both domestically and internationally, which created a diverse industrial membership and increased mentor knowledge base and opportunities for PIs and students from particiating university sites.

  • The PIs at CSM were able to strengthen and expand center membership in existing and new areas, and enhance cross site collaboration to support existing projects and develop new projects. New areas/projects that have been identified include H2 embrittlment in pipeline steels and stress relaxation cracking in stainless steels and Ni-base alloys.

(2) Created an collaborative environemnt for students and faculty to meet and work with experts from participating university sites and industry mentors. 

  • The PIs worked actively to invovle faculty, students, and industry members on a regular base through monthly meetings and frequentely updated shared folders to ensure that projects had strong industry mentorship for faculty and students.

(3) Increased awareness of welding engineering and metal additive manufacturing as an educational and career option for K-12 students and those early on in their college education, while focusing on creating an inclusive environment that supports a diverse student body. 

  • The Open Weld Lab program initiated by the PIs offers weld training to both graduate and undergraduate students on campus, offering high school internship program with strong emphasis on diverse students, and supporting STEM outreach programs for local elementary and middle school students especially for disadvantaged public schools, in order to foster a diverse STEM pipeline for the future generation of joining/welding technicians, engineers, and scientists.
  • The PIs also supported an elementary school science fair and Women in 3D printing Colorado section meetings

For the report period between 8/1/2022 and 7/31/2023, there were three active projects including:

  • Characterization of Directed Energy Deposition for Pressure Boundary Components (Collaborators: EPRI and Oak Ridge National Laboratory)
  • Inoculated High Strength Aluminum Feedstocks for Welding and Directed Energy Deposition (DED) (Collaborators: Fortius Metals and Elementum 3D)
  • Weldability and Creep Resistance of Additively Manufactured 316L for Power Generation Applications (Collaborators: EPRI and Naval Nuclear Laboratory)

These AM-related projects provided a better understanding of the current state of Wire Arc (WA) -DED of stainless steels, how build parameters impact properties and the effects of defects within the build, and supported changes to ASME code to allow for use of WA-DED components in nuclear power plants. They provideed knowledge on how parameters affect microstructural properties and how to control final properties by altering WA-DED parameters. The PIs invovled also developed and delivered courses on "Solidification" and "Advanced Weld Metallurgy" in support of educational mission of the center.

In 2023, cross-site collaboration was also enhanced. Two projects are being developed that invovles PIs and Students from three participating university sites, including CSM, Ohio State UInivesity and University of Tennessee, wwhich invovle multiple domestic and international industrial members.  

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.


 


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Zhenzhen Yu

Manufacturing and Materials Joining Research Center (Ma2JIC) was originally founded in 2010 as CIMJSEA in Phase I, which focused primarily on energy sector materials joining applications. As the Center membership and market evolved, our Phase II center reflected those changes and our widened focus on manufacturing and materials joining.


During the entire life of this award, Ma2JIC has establisheda collaborative research environment between universities and industrial partners that promotes the development and application of fundamental knowledge in materials joining and metal additive manufacturing and provides a platform for the education of the next generation of scientists and engineers. Overall outcomes at the Colorado School of Mines (CSM) site include:


(1) Active outreach efforts were made both domestically and internationally, which created a diverse industrial membership and increased mentor knowledge base and opportunities for PIs and students from particiating university sites.

The PIs at CSM were able to strengthen and expand center membership in existing and new areas, and enhance cross site collaboration to support existing projects and develop new projects. New areas/projects that have been identified include H2 embrittlment in pipeline steels and stress relaxation cracking in stainless steels and Ni-base alloys.



(2) Created an collaborative environemnt for students and faculty to meet and work with experts from participating university sites and industry mentors.

The PIs worked actively to invovle faculty, students, and industry members on a regular base through monthly meetings and frequentely updated shared folders to ensure that projects had strong industry mentorship for faculty and students.



(3)Increased awareness of welding engineering and metal additive manufacturing as an educational and career option for K-12 students and those early on in their college education, while focusing on creating an inclusive environment that supports a diverse student body.

The Open Weld Lab program initiated by the PIs offers weld training to both graduate and undergraduate students on campus, offering high school internship program with strong emphasis on diverse students, and supporting STEM outreach programs for local elementary and middle school students especially for disadvantaged public schools, in order to foster a diverse STEM pipeline for the future generation of joining/welding technicians, engineers, and scientists.
The PIs also supported an elementary school science fair and Women in 3D printing Colorado section meetings



For the report period between 8/1/2022 and 7/31/2023, there were three active projects including:

Characterization of Directed Energy Deposition for Pressure Boundary Components (Collaborators: EPRI and Oak Ridge National Laboratory)
Inoculated High Strength Aluminum Feedstocks for Welding and Directed Energy Deposition (DED) (Collaborators: Fortius Metals and Elementum 3D)
Weldability and Creep Resistance of Additively Manufactured 316L for Power Generation Applications (Collaborators: EPRI and Naval Nuclear Laboratory)



These AM-related projects provided a better understanding of the current state of Wire Arc (WA) -DED of stainless steels, how build parameters impact properties and the effects of defects within the build, and supported changes to ASME code to allow for use of WA-DED components in nuclear power plants. They provideed knowledge on how parameters affect microstructural properties and how to control final properties by altering WA-DED parameters. The PIs invovled also developed and delivered courses on "Solidification" and "Advanced Weld Metallurgy" in support of educational mission of the center.


In 2023, cross-site collaboration was also enhanced. Two projects are being developed that invovles PIs and Students from three participating university sites, including CSM, Ohio State UInivesity and University of Tennessee, wwhich invovle multiple domestic and international industrial members.
